entry.title: Combined summary - Civ Kit: A Peer-to-Peer Electronic Market System
entry.summary: The discussion revolves around the concept of front-running in a peer-to-peer market system. Front-running refers to entering into a trade with advance knowledge of a block transaction that will influence the price of the underlying security. The participants involved in this context are Mary the Maker, Terry the Taker, and Bob the bulletin board operator.The process begins with Mary publishing a limit order to buy a derivative. Bob, as the bulletin board operator, has the option to execute against Mary's order. If Bob decides not to execute, he relays the order to Terry the Taker and other subscribers to Bob's market. Terry then has the option to execute a trade against Mary's limit order. If Terry chooses not to execute, Mary's order remains on the bulletin board.The concern raised is that this model resembles a brokerage rather than an exchange market structure. It is suggested that Terry should open his own brokerage and compete on quoting prices with Bob. By comparing Bob and Terry on metrics like execution quality, more market activity can be drawn since they are providing better prices.The issue of front-running is seen as a positive problem to have, as it indicates active participants and liquidity in the market. The focus should be on identifying the products people are interested in trading and providing them with a good user experience. Other security paradigms to mitigate front-running are discussed, such as duplicating the announcement of offers to multiple boards operated by independent identities and running the bulletin boards as a federation.The context also emphasizes the importance of reputation frameworks and incentive structures for service operators in the market. A Web-of-Stakes, composed of economic weights assigned to market entities based on the Bitcoin UTXO set, is proposed as a way to score trades and counterparties. Incentives for service operators can be provided through privacy-preserving credentials backed by Bitcoin payments.Antoine Riard, along with Nicholas Gregory and Ray Youssef, has been working on a peer-to-peer market system that enables censorship-resistant and permissionless global trading. The design combines the Nostr architecture of simple relays announcing trade orders to their clients with Lightning onion routing infrastructure. The market boards are Nostr relays with a Lightning gateway, operating autonomously and in competition. Trades are escrowed under Bitcoin Script contracts, relying on moderations and know your peer oracles for adjudication.One feedback received on the paper publication was the lack of underscoring front-running resistance as a fundamental property desired for a peer-to-peer marketplace. The level of front-running resistance aimed by market participants is expected to be influenced by the types of trades considered. For some classes of goods, the level of item liquidity may vary due to production cycles and external factors like weather. Different types of trade marketplaces may be exposed to different levels of front-running risks and have to deal with accurate risk modeling of the underlying goods.Two security paradigms are proposed to mitigate front-running in a peer-to-peer marketplace. The first is duplicating the announcement of offers to multiple concurrent boards operated by independent identities and monitoring the latency. Latency anomalies can be detected by watchtower-like infrastructure, and misbehaving boards can be disqualified by makers. Another paradigm involves running the bulletin boards as a federation using Honey Badger BFT, as used by Fedimint. Consensus proposals must be adopted before offers become consensus items announced to all federation members' onion gateways.Scoring trades, counterparties, and service operators can be enabled by introducing a Web-of-Stakes. Economic weights can be assigned to each market entity based on the Bitcoin UTXO set, serving as a trustless source of truth. This reputation paradigm can be combined with decentralized identifiers to create a consistent incentive framework for service operators. Privacy-preserving credentials backed by Bitcoin payments, similar to IETF's Privacy Pass, can be utilized for incentivization.The whitepaper delves into the architecture of the system, with plans to release code and modules gradually. The researchers are building on top of the Lightning Dev Kit and Nostr libraries and aim to collaborate with the community for standardizing libraries and ensuring interoperability between clients. Feedback is encouraged and welcomed.
